items.title: SSL: CERTIFICATE_VERIFY_FAILED on stock.info and stock.financials
items.body:
```
import yfinance as yf
msft = yf.Ticker("msft")
msft.info
msft.financials
```

so... most other functions are working... but `info` and `financials` are throwing ```SSLCertVerificationError: [SSL: CERTIFICATE_VERIFY_FAILED] certificate verify failed: unable to get local issuer certificate (_ssl.c:1076)``` error. I got lazy and stopped testing others after financials, but pretty much went down the list from ```info``` on your README.md


I might have missed something but overall it's not a major issue since I just use ```yf.download``` to get most of the info that I need. Thanks for the great stuff!

items.title: Limited Success (lxml not found) - Is the API blocked?
items.body:
Just installed version 0.1.54 of yfinance.
(Using Python 3.7.3 and running through a Jupyter notebook.)

Going through the types of data I am getting the 'lxml not found' error.

Based on other posted comments it seems that Yahoo has been blocking the traditional API's to get this data - possibly to force use of "premium service" (???), I don't know but seems likely since the ones that work (history, actions, dividends, splits, options) versus the more useful ones that do not work (info, financials, balance_sheet, cash flow etc. - tried all listed).

Please bring me up to speed if I am missing something - but otherwise my thinking is that yfinance is a very useful program that unfortunately is hampered by an uncooperative data website.

items.title: Institutional Holders Missing
items.body:
In https://github.com/ranaroussi/yfinance/blob/master/yfinance/base.py

```
        # holders
        url = "{}/{}/holders".format(self._scrape_url, self.ticker)
        holders = _pd.read_html(url)
        self._major_holders = holders[0]
        self._institutional_holders = holders[1] # --> If missing, will crash <--
        if 'Date Reported' in self._institutional_holders:
            self._institutional_holders['Date Reported'] = _pd.to_datetime(
                self._institutional_holders['Date Reported'])
        if '% Out' in self._institutional_holders:
            self._institutional_holders['% Out'] = self._institutional_holders[
                '% Out'].str.replace('%', '').astype(float)/100
```

yfinance is looking for institutional holders in `holders[1]` if element is missing the script will crash.

items.title: Intelligent caching of yfinance results not implemented
items.body:
This would be a feature request.  But in reality it is not.  For the very future viability of this project, the amount of requests hammering yahoo which especially for parsing web data is not officially allowed, should be minimized.

The easiest thing is to add a new module e.g. TickerCache, which checks for a file `<TickerName>.data.csv` that contains all information about the stock (info, financials, balance sheet, cashflow, sustainability, history, options).  This way the whole history need not be refatched but only from the end of the history in the file to current time.  The time can be used to decide if 3 months has elapsed on the quarterly or a year for yearly financial data before re-retrieving those.  The details of market trading hours can also be used for even fetching day-to-day history.

I will submit a PR with a good amount of the propose code.

A major reason I requested timezone support was to deal with all the mechanics of this.  I already have it implemented in my projects.  It should be a de facto standard for this tool.  Anyone doing serious work with this likely requires it as well.

items.title: Dates are not timezone aware + datetimes/floats not used in fundamentals
items.body:
All dates should technically be converted to be in the Olson timezone 'America/New_York'

e.g.
```datetime.now().astimezone(pytz.timezone('America/New_York'))```

```hist.index = hist.index.tz_localize('America/New_York')```

```tick.info['exchangeTimezoneName']``` contains the appropriate time zone for case of non NASDAQ or NYSE stocks.

First way requires simply importing pytz, and for the financials and history calling astimezone() as above.

However with Pandas, the tz_localize does not require an import.

Fundamentals are not using columns with datetimes (including tz-aware), nor does it convert the data to floats for processing.

items.title: Excessive HTML requests used, additional easily retrievable data not gotten
items.body:
The app may want to stop using and relying on Pandas tables for the financials and info as all of these can be fetched with a single call with a serious amount of additional information.

I provide the very straight-forward and simple parsing code to achieve this effect:
```
scrape_url = 'https://finance.yahoo.com/quote'
url = '%s/%s/%s' % (scrape_url, StockName, 'financials')
req = requests.get(url=url)
idx = req.text.find('root.App.main = ')
j = json.loads(re.sub('root.App.main = ', '', req.text[idx:].split('\n')[0])[:-1])
j['context']
j['context']['dispatcher']['stores']['StreamDataStore']['quoteData'][StockName] #contains Ticker.info
j['context']['dispatcher']['stores']['QuoteSummaryStore'].keys()
dict_keys(['cashflowStatementHistory', 'balanceSheetHistoryQuarterly', 'earnings', 'price', 'incomeStatementHistoryQuarterly', 'incomeStatementHistory', 'balanceSheetHistory', 'cashflowStatementHistoryQuarterly', 'quoteType', 'summaryDetail', 'symbol', 'pageViews'])
```

The rest of the puzzle to parse it into the table data (so you get the correct ordering and correct string captions) can be found in this javascript file:
https://s.yimg.com/uc/finance/dd-site/js/Quote.financials.938c6b86ad7b69ba7927.min.js

items.title: Precision issues with adjusted historical closing prices.
items.body:
The actual closing price for AAPL on 1980-12-12 is 28.75.
Using yfinance, the result is $0.51.  Adjusting for splits gives us:
0.51 * 56 = 28.56
This is off by 0.19.
The reason is because you are using 'priceHint' to round the closing values.  The actual downloaded value is 0.513393
0.513393 * 56 = 28.750008
I'm not sure why this is being rounded, but it is causing presplit closing values to be inaccurate.  The more splits a company has had, the bigger the effect on the actual value.

items.title: Problem catching/handling ValueError
items.body:
Hi, thanks for a great piece of software.
I have a small problem, I have a (fairly large) list of tickers that I'm feeding in to yf.download().
Some times Yahoo doesn't have a lot of data for all the tickers I ask for (for example, very small stocks on the Stockholm exchange sometimes shows no history at all) and when this happens yfinance throws an error:

ValueError: ('FEEL.ST', 'No data found for this date range, symbol may be delisted')

I'd like to catch this error, so I can try to get the data from somewhere else, but trying to do so opens up two separate problems:

If I run yf.download threaded, as per default, I can't catch the error at all. The upside is that it keeps downloading all the rest of the data, so I get most of what I need. I just don't know exactly what I'm missing.

If i run yf.download with threads=False I can catch the error, but at the same time it stops downloading the rest of the data.

I guess in the first case I could examine the data downloaded and look for NaN's, and in the second case I could manually skip the error-generating ticker and proceed with the rest, but I'd just like to see if anyone else has run in to the same problem and have an elegant solution?

Thanks!

items.title: DataFrame constructor not properly called
items.body:
When using Python 3.5.6, Pandas 23.4, and fix-yahoo-finance 0.1.28, I get the error below. 

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/yahoo/yahoo_data_fetcher.py", line 9, in <module>
    data = pdr.get_data_yahoo("SPY", start="2017-01-01", end="2017-06-15")
  File "/lib/python3.5/site-packages/fix_yahoo_finance/__init__.py", line 350, in download
    actions=actions, auto_adjust=auto_adjust)
  File "/lib/python3.5/site-packages/fix_yahoo_finance/__init__.py", line 290, in _download_one
    actions=actions, auto_adjust=auto_adjust)
  File "/lib/python3.5/site-packages/fix_yahoo_finance/__init__.py", line 247, in history
    dividends, splits = self._parse_actions(data["chart"]["result"][0])
  File "/lib/python3.5/site-packages/fix_yahoo_finance/__init__.py", line 127, in _parse_actions
    dividends = _pd.DataFrame(data["events"]["dividends"].values())
  File "/lib/python3.5/site-packages/pandas/core/frame.py", line 422, in __init__
    raise ValueError('DataFrame constructor not properly called!')
ValueError: DataFrame constructor not properly called!
```

I was able to fix it locally by wrapping the values dict's in `_parse_actions()` in a list:

```
if "events" in data:
            if "dividends" in data["events"]:
                dividends = _pd.DataFrame(list(data["events"]["dividends"].values()))    # <-- Here
                dividends.set_index("date", inplace=True)
                dividends.index = _pd.to_datetime(dividends.index, unit="s")
                dividends.sort_index(inplace=True)
                dividends.columns = ["Dividends"]

            if "splits" in data["events"]:
                splits = _pd.DataFrame(list(data["events"]["splits"].values()))    # <-- Here
                splits.set_index("date", inplace=True)
                splits.index = _pd.to_datetime(
                    splits.index, unit="s")
                splits.sort_index(inplace=True)
                splits["Stock Splits"] = splits["numerator"] / \
                    splits["denominator"]
                splits = splits["Stock Splits"]
```

I think its related to specifically looking for certain columns in the scraped data. The error message is "KeyError: "['Open' 'High' 'Low' 'Close' 'Adj Close' 'Volume'] not in index". You can replicate the problem in version 0.0.21 by calling the download function with actions="only", and as_panel=False.

items.title: yf.download start & end dates error
items.body:
The download function just works when the start & end date parameters are static strings, the problem comes when you try to format a date value to string, the download function does not recognize the parameters and throws and error.

```
import fix_yahoo_finance as yf
import datetime as dt

actual_date = dt.date.today()
last_month_date = actual_date - dt.timedelta(days=30)

data = yf.download("SPY", start=actual_date.isoformat(), end=last_month_date.isoformat())
df = pd.DataFrame(data=data)
```

The solution to this is creating static strings, f.e.:
```
actual_date = "2017-09-22"
last_month_date = "2017-10-11"
```

This way you can't create dynamic date requests, bc there's a formar error. I've also tried using 

> actual_date = actual_date.strftime('%Y-%m-%d')

and it doesn't work neither.

Good luck, thank you!
